pageData.text: The fashion industry has been heavily criticized for how much water it uses to produce clothing. The industry has also been criticized for the pollution it creates through the process of dying materials. However, new technologies and a little help from bacteria, such as E. coli, might change that.

Genetically engineered strains of bacteria can produce massive amounts of natural dyes. Microbially-produced dyes do not contain harmful pollutants such as salts, acids, and formaldehyde. The hope is that by harnessing the dye-secreting power of bacteria, the fashion industry can use at least 49% less water and 35% less electricity, thus dramatically reducing its carbon emissions and pollution<sup>1</sup>.

pageData.subTitle: Bacteria Cell Structure
pageData.text: Bacterial cells can be found in just about every environment in nature. Bacterial cells are very small, typically about 0.2 μm in diameter. Thus, to see individual cells and groups of cells, a microscope is necessary.

A bacterial cell is similar to a cell in a plant or an animal. For example, these cells all contain genetic material, cytoplasm, and a . Like a plant cell, bacterial cells get their structure from a rigid . Some bacteria have an that covers their cell wall in addition to the cell membrane found beneath the cell wall. The outermost layer of any bacterial cell is the . Composed of complex sugars and proteins, the capsule not only enhances the ability of the bacteria to cause disease but also protects the cell from engulfment by larger cells. Many bacteria have special structures, such as (for sticking to other cells and surfaces) or (for propelling the cell forward).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Parts of a bacterial cell

pageData.subTitle: Bacteria Characteristics
pageData.text: Prokaryotic bacterial cells are much smaller and simpler in structure than eukaryotic cells. Stained bacteria can be described in terms of their (shapes) and . A first step in identifying bacterial species is determining the cell morphology. Single cells can be rods , spirals or spherical . There can be slight variations in morphology to include short rods (), flexible spirals (), and slightly curved rods .

Cell arrangements can also be used to identify bacterial species. Arrangements are determined by the number of planes of division and if the cells separate after division. Cocci and bacilli commonly form multicellular associations, including attached daughter cells (<button class='glossary-text'>diplococcus</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>diplobacillus</button>) and continued division in the same plane results in long chains (<button class='glossary-text'>streptococcus</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>streptobacillus</button>). A tetrad (<button class='glossary-text'>tetracoccus</button>) is formed if a second division occurs perpendicular to the first division, and a <button class='glossary-text'>sarcina</button> forms when a cube-shaped arrangement of cells occurs. An irregular cluster of cells (<button class='glossary-text'>staphylococcus</button>) results from irregular division planes. Spirilla are rarely seen in arrangements other than single cells.

pageData.subTitle: Staining
pageData.text: Many bacterial cells are colorless, so there is little contrast to distinguish them from the surface of the microscope slide. Staining the bacterial cells adds contrast for ease of viewing. techniques help microbiologists see bacterial cells more easily with a microscope. Addition of just one type of stain is called simple staining and is used mainly to visualize, not categorize, bacterial cells. More advanced staining techniques, such as and , use multiple stains and can be used for identification and classification purposes.

Most dyes used to stain cells are molecules with a charged portion, called the <button class='glossary-text'>chromophore</button>, contained in a solvent (usually ethanol or water). If dissolved in a solution, the chromophores are attracted to cellular structures bearing the opposite charge and repelled by those bearing the same charge.

A negatively charged chromophore, characteristic of an , is attracted to positively charged cellular structures and repelled by negatively charged ones. Because bacterial cells typically have a negative surface charge, acidic stains are strongly repelled by them. The cell will remain clear and colorless, but the stain will adhere to the surface of the slide (see Figure 3). Examples of acidic stains include nigrosin and India ink.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A negatively stained bacteria

pageData.text: A positively charged , characteristic of a , is attracted to negatively charged cellular structures and repelled by positively charged ones. Because bacterial cells typically have a negative surface charge, basic stains are strongly attracted to them. The stained cell will appear dark against the unstained surface of the microscope slide (see Figure 4). Examples of basic stains are methylene blue, , and .

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A differential stain distinguishes Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.subTitle: Simple Vs. Differential
pageData.text: Differential stains require the application of more than one stain to the bacterial cells. This technique enables microbiologists to distinguish between different groups of bacteria. Figure 4 shows an example of a differential stain where two different types of bacteria are present in the same sample.

pageData.subTitle: Gram Stain
pageData.text: Before you stain a slide for viewing, the slide must be prepared so that the bacteria remain on the slide. This procedure is referred to as making a <button class='glossary-text'>bacterial emulsion</button> (smear), where the bacterial cells are <button class='glossary-text'>heat fixed</button> to the slide. This procedure kills the bacteria and makes them adhere to the slide. The application of colored dyes to the prepared slides allows the bacteria to become visible when viewed with a microscope.

The Gram stain is the most common technique (see Figure 6). It is used to distinguish among bacteria based on the composition of the . bacteria have a large quantity of a polymer called in their cell walls. bacteria have a much smaller amount of peptidoglycan, but their cell walls are covered by an (see Figure 5).

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
Figure 6: Steps in the Gram-staining technique

pageData.text: , the purple primary stain, is applied to the bacterial smear. It initially stains all cells purple. is then applied to act as a —a substance used to “set” a stain. Iodine causes the crystal violet to become more closely associated with .

The crystal violet is rinsed off with a <button class='glossary-text'>decolorizer</button>, usually ethyl alcohol. <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-positive</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-negative</button> cells react differently to decolorizers. Gram-positive cells remain purple because their abundant peptidoglycan holds the primary stain. Gram-negative cells lose their color because the <button class='glossary-text'>outer membrane</button> dissolves and the primary stain releases from the scant peptidoglycan layer.

<button class='glossary-text'>Safranin</button>, the red <button class='glossary-text'>counterstain</button>, is applied. The safranin adds pink or red color to the Gram-negative cells. It actually stains all the cells but is not visible against the dark purple of Gram-positive cells. The counterstain is rinsed off with water, and the slide is blotted dry and ready to view.

The application of colored dyes to the prepared slide allows the bacteria to become visible when viewed with a microscope. The Gram stain is the most common differential staining technique. It is used to distinguish among bacteria based on the composition of the cell wall. Gram-positive bacteria have a large quantity of a polymer called peptidoglycan in their cell walls. Gram-negative bacteria have a much smaller amount of peptidoglycan, but their cell walls are covered by an outer membrane. Crystal violet, the purple primary stain, is applied to the bacterial smear to differentiate between these two types of bacteria. It initially stains all cells purple. Iodine is then applied to set the stain by causing the crystal violet to become more closely associated with peptidoglycan. In order to contrast the appearance of Gram-negative cells against Gram-positive cells, a red counterstain (safranin) is applied to the slide.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, set up your microscope, disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and prepare your cultures. In activity 1, rinse the slides in ethanol. Then, draw circles on and label each slide. Next, add water to each circle and inoculate the water drop using a loop from your bacterial culture. When you have inoculated 6 circles with appropriate bacteria, pass the slides through a candle flame. In activity 2, add stain to the circles on the slide. Then, let the slide set for the required staining time and then rinse the stain off the slide. When you have stained 3 slides, observe the smear under the microscope. You will observe all 6 smears. You will then proceed to activity 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, create 8 new bacterial smears on 4 slides. Next, stain with crystal violet, then gram iodine, rinse with ethanol, then stain with safranin. This staining is repeated for all 4 slides. Next, observe the smears under a microscope. Then, create a bacterial smear using a cheek sample. Next, stain with crystal violet, then gram iodine, rinse with ethanol, then stain with safranin. Observe the smear under a microscope. Finally, observe an optional prepared slide and compare it to your slides.

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced.

Culture RecommendationsYou will need relatively fresh cultures, preferably in broth, of Escherichia coli, Micrococcus luteus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Serratia marcesens for this investigation to be successful.
  • If you have cultures of these organisms that are no more than two weeks old, you may skip “Preparation” Steps 9–16.
  • If you need to reactivate lyophilized cultures, follow the instructions that came with the culture using proper aseptic technique and incubate until growth is apparent in the tryptic soy broth. You may wish to first review the video.

Then skip “Preparation” Steps 9–16, and proceed to the activities.
  • If you have reactivated cultures that are more than two weeks old, carry out all the “Preparation” steps before proceeding to the activities.
  • All the organisms will grow at room temperature; however, E. coli and S. epidermidis will grow faster around 37 °C (99 °F).
Follow your instructor’s directions on which cultures to keep and which to discard at the end of this investigation.

In Activity 1, you will prepare bacterial smears on microscope slides to use in Activity 2.
Fill a plastic pipette with ethanol.
Hold a glass slide over the sink, and use the ethanol to gently rinse the slide, allowing the liquid to flow off the end of the slide.
Place the slide on a paper towel, and allow it to air-dry.
Repeat Steps 1–3 using the same pipette until you have disinfected three slides.
Use the grease pencil to draw 2 dime-size circles on each of your slides. The circles should not overlap or touch the edges of the slide.
Label the slides “1,” “2,” and “3.” On each slide, label one of the circles “A” and the other circle “B.” Do not write inside the circles.
In Data Table 1, record which bacteria you will use to create smears within each drawn circle. The bacteria you choose for each circle does not matter as long as each species is used at least once.
Unwrap a new sterile plastic pipette, and fill it with distilled or bottled water. Place 1 drop of water in each of the circles.

Using a new inoculating loop, transfer one small loop of Escherichia coli broth to the water droplet that corresponds to the placement of the E. coli smear you recorded in Step 7. Mix the bacteria with the water, and spread it out within the circle as shown in Figure 7. Repeat this step for any other E. coli smears you recorded in Step 7. Place the loop in the disposal jar.

pageData.text: Repeat Step 9 for each of the other bacteria cultures. Use a new inoculating loop for each transfer.

When preparing bacterial smears, the number of bacteria transferred will impact the quality of your stained slide. Too much or too little bacteria can impact both staining time and clarity of the microorganisms. Your smearing technique will get better with practice.

pageData.text: The Gram-staining technique takes practice. Preparing multiple sets of slides in advance will allow you to perfect your technique. As long as the smears are , they can be stained at a later time.
Review all the activity instructions before you begin. The decolorization step is the most critical and is where most staining errors occur.
Arrange all materials so they are within easy reach.
Select one of the slides you prepared in Activity 3A and place it on several thicknesses of paper towel.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Add about 5 drops of <button class='glossary-text'>crystal violet</button> to each smear until the smears are completely covered. Allow the stain to sit for 1 minute.
Fill a pipette with distilled or bottled water. Hold the slide over the sink, and use the water to gently rinse the bacterial smears, allowing the liquid to flow off the end of the slide.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Place the slide back on the paper towels. Use the medicine dropper to add about 5 drops of Gram <button class='glossary-text'>iodine</button> to each smear until the smears are completely covered. Allow the stain to sit for 1 minute.

Fill a pipette with distilled or bottled water. Hold the slide over the sink, and use the water to gently rinse the slide smears, allowing the liquid to flow off the end of the slide. Keep the water close by for Step 9.
Fill a pipette with ethanol. Holding the slide over the sink at an angle, apply the ethanol by allowing it to trickle over the smears until the slide runoff is clear.
Immediately rinse the slide with distilled or bottled water while still holding it over the sink.

Variable results in a Gram stain are usually a result of poor decolorizing technique. The ethanol is actively working until it is rinsed off with water. Such over-decolorizing results in reddish <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-positive</button> cells. Under-decolorizing results in purple <button class='glossary-text'>Gram-negative</button> cells.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Place the slide back on the paper towels. Add about 5 drops of <button class='glossary-text'>safranin</button> to each smear until the smears are completely covered. Allow the <button class='glossary-text'>counterstain</button> to sit for 1 minute.
Fill a pipette with distilled or bottled water. Hold the slide over the sink, and use the water to gently rinse the smears, allowing the liquid to flow off the end of the slide.
Gently blot the slide dry with a clean sheet of paper towel. Do not rub the slide dry.
Repeat Steps 3–12 for each of the remaining slides.

Using a microscope, examine one of the smears on Slide 1. Begin by using the scanning or low power objective. Look for an area of the slide where the cells are evenly distributed and where there are few, if any, large clumps of cells.
Switch to a higher magnification. Follow your instructor’s directions as to whether oil immersion should be used.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Draw or take a photo of the cells you observe in the smear. Observe the shape, , color, and Gram reaction of the cells. Record your observations in Data Table 3.
Repeat Steps 14–16 for the other smear on Slide 1. You can also observe the other version of Slide 1 you prepared if your chosen slide did not yield satisfactory results.
Repeat Steps 14–17 for Slide 2.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Gram Stain Control Slide (8 steps)

pageData.text: Disinfect a new glass slide using ethanol, and allow it to air-dry.
Unwrap a new sterile plastic pipette, and fill it with distilled or bottled water. Place one drop of water in the center of the slide.
Wash your hands well with soap and water, especially if you have recently handled bacterial cultures.

Use a toothpick to gently scrape your teeth along the gumline (gingival pockets). Do not gouge your gums. The gumline is where bacteria in your mouth like to hang out and, in some cases, produce acids that can cause cavities to form.
Transfer the sample to your slide by gently swirling the toothpick tip in the water droplet. Discard the toothpick in the garbage. Allow the slide to air-dry.

Using a match or lighter, light the liquid paraffin candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol. Hold the slide using the forceps, and pass the slide through the flame two or three times. Allow the slide to cool.
Follow the Gram-staining procedure in Activity 3, Section B, Steps 3–12, to stain the slide.

Use a microscope to magnify the bacteria sample. Draw or take a photo of the cells you observe. Note the shape, arrangement, color, and Gram reaction of the cells. Record your image and observations in Data Table 3.

typeBefore.title:
D
 Comparing Slides to a Prepared Control Slide (5 steps)
typeBefore.text: Note: If your instructor did not have you work with the prepared stained slides that came with your kit, omit this section.

pageData.text: Obtain the prepared stained slide from another investigation. This is your prepared control slide.

Use a microscope to examine the slide. Begin by using the scanning or low power objective. Look for an area of the slide where the cells are evenly distributed and where there appears to be both Gram-positive and Gram-negative cells.
Switch to a higher magnification. Follow your instructor’s directions as to whether oil immersion should be used.
Draw or take a photo of the cells you observe. Note the shape, arrangement, color, and Gram reaction of the cells. Record your image and observations in Data Table 3.
Compare this slide to your Gram-stained slides.

text: Discard the paper towels and pipettes in the garbage.

The glass slides should be disposed of as though they are broken glass —wrap the glass slides in newspapers, paper bags, or other sturdy paper, tape the paper securely shut, and place it in the trash. This prevents anyone who handles the trash from cutting themselves should the glass break. These materials can also be put into a container, such as a small cardboard box, that can be sealed and disposed of in the trash.

pageData.text:
To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops, pipettes, etc.), soak them in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes. Then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol. Wrap the materials in an opaque plastic bag, and discard it in the garbage.
Keep your broth cultures of M. luteus and S. marcesens for later use unless otherwise directed by your instructor.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed and the used culture vial and stopper, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. Open each tube, vial, or plate while submerged in the bleach solution. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected items in an opaque plastic bag, and discard it in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean it with soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.

text: Why do we stain bacterial cells?
Explain the difference between a simple stain and a differential stain. Please give examples of each type of staining.
Explain the structural difference between gram-positive and gram-negative bacterial cells that results in the different colors when stained.
Why do the slides have to be heat fixed before staining? What do you think would happen if the slides were not heat fixed and then stained?
In a simple stain what would be the consequence of leaving a stain on for too long? What would be the result if you did not leave the stain on long enough?

Using the information from the lab, predict what would happen if you made the following mistakes completing your Gram stain.
  1. Failure to apply the decolorizer
1. Failure to add the iodine
1. Failure to apply the safranin
1. Applying the safranin before the crystal violet
1. Applying too many bacterial cells to the smear
1. Not leaving the crystal violet on for a full minute
Compare and contrast your Gram stain slides to the prepared gram stain slides. How are they similar and how are they different? What do you think caused these differences?
Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria respond differently to antibiotics. Please explain why this is and the implications this has for antibiotic treatment in individuals.

There are other staining procedures beyond simple staining and differential staining. Examples include endospore, acid-fast, capsule, and flagella stains. Please pick one staining technique to research and answer the following questions:
  • What is the theory behind the staining technique, what stains are used, how are they applied, what portion of the bacteria are they reacting with?
  • How is this stain used to differentiate or identify bacterial cells or cell structures?
  • Describe the staining technique. List and describe the steps as necessary.
  • Give examples of the bacterial species or structures that are identified with your stain.
  • Give an example of how this stain would be used in a health care setting.
  • Find (and cite) a picture example of your staining technique.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, set up your microscope, disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and prepare your cultures. In activity 1, rinse the slides in ethanol. Then, draw circles on and label each slide. Next, add water to each circle and inoculate the water drop using a loop from your bacterial culture. When you have inoculated 6 circles with appropriate bacteria, pass the slides through a candle flame. In activity 2, add stain to the circles on the slide. Then, let the slide set for the required staining time and then rinse the stain off the slide. When you have stained 3 slides, observe the smear under the microscope. You will observe all 6 smears. You will then proceed to activity 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 3 of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, create 8 new bacterial smears on 4 slides. Next, stain with crystal violet, then gram iodine, rinse with ethanol, then stain with safranin. This staining is repeated for all 4 slides. Next, observe the smears under a microscope. Then, create a bacterial smear using a cheek sample. Next, stain with crystal violet, then gram iodine, rinse with ethanol, then stain with safranin. Observe the smear under a microscope. Finally, observe an optional prepared slide and compare it to your slides.

data.title: Acidic stain
data.content: A dye characterized by a negatively-charged chromophore; when applied, bacterial cells will remain colorless but the slide background will be colored

data.title: Arrangement
data.content: The spatial organization of cells as determined by the number of planes of division (if the cells separate after division)

data.title: Bacilli/bacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria

data.title: Bacterial emulsion
data.content: A dry film of a bacterial culture fixed to a microscope slide in preparation for staining; also called a bacterial smear

data.title: Basic stain
data.content: A dye characterized by a positively-charged chromophore; when applied, bacterial cells will be stained but the slide background will be colorless

data.title: Capsule
data.content: The outermost layer of a bacterial cell

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Chromophore
data.content: An atom or group whose presence is responsible for the color of a compound

data.title: Cocci/coccus
data.content: Spherical bacteria

data.title: Coccobacilli
data.content: Short rod-shaped bacteria; singular, coccobacillus

data.title: Counterstain
data.content: A stain that colors the cells not already colored by another stain

data.title: Crystal violet
data.content: A purple stain; it is the primary stain used in Gram staining

data.title: Decolorizer
data.content: In Gram staining, this substance removes the stain from Gram-negative cells without affecting the stain of Gram-positive cells

data.title: Differential staining
data.content: The process of visualizing bacteria cells by the addition of more than one dye to differentiate between multiple species

data.title: Diplobacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria arranged as pairs joined end to end

data.title: Diplococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged as joined pairs

data.title: Flagella
data.content: Long thin appendages that extend beyond the cell wall and propel the cell along; singular, flagellum

data.title: Gram-negative
data.content: Bacteria that have a few layers of peptidoglycan located in the periplasmic space

data.title: Gram-positive
data.content: Bacteria that have numerous layers of peptidoglycan that lie outside the periplasmic space

data.title: Heat fixed
data.content: When the process of using heat to kill and adhere bacteria to a slide is applied

data.title: Iodine
data.content: In Gram staining, this substance sets the primary stain by helping it adhere to bacterial cell walls

data.title: Mordant
data.content: A substance that fixes a dye or stain in a material when the two are combined

data.title: Morphologies
data.content: Shapes of an organism

data.title: Outer membrane
data.content: A membrane that covers the cell wall of a bacteria in addition to the cell (cytoplasmic) membrane

data.title: Peptidoglycan
data.content: A polymer that forms the cell walls of many bacteria

data.title: Pili
data.content: Hair-like appendages on the surface of many bacteria; singular, pilus

data.title: Safranin
data.content: A biological stain used as a counterstain in Gram staining

data.title: Sarcina
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in a cube shape

data.title: Simple staining
data.content: The process of visualizing bacteria cells by the addition of just one stain

data.title: Special staining
data.content: The process of visualizing bacteria cells by making certain structures visible under a microscope

data.title: Spirilla/spirillum
data.content: Rigid, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Spirochetes
data.content: Flexible, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Staphylococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in irregular clusters as they continuously divide along irregular division planes

data.title: Streptobacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria arranged in long chains as they divide continuously along the same plane

data.title: Streptococcus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in long chains as they divide continuously along the same plane

data.title: Tetracoccus
data.content: Spherical bacteria arranged in a group of four cells when a second division occurs perpendicular to the first division

data.title: Vibrios
data.content: Slightly curved rod-shaped bacteria
